text: hello this is chef john from
foodwishes.com
with
spiced apple chutney
that's right forget everything you
thought you knew about applesauce well
that didn't take long but anyway forget
everything you thought you knew because
this easy apple chutney is more
beautiful more delicious and way more
interesting and if you're thinking that
sounds great except my family's not
going to eat anything called apple
chutney well as they say down in
australia no worries we'll just let you
call it homemade applesauce and they'll
never know the difference so anyway
let's get started and like almost all
chutneys this one starts with sugar
just regular white sugar
and plain old white distilled vinegar
and yes you can use different sugars you
can use part or all brown sugar you
could definitely use different vinegars
but i do prefer the more neutrally
flavored white sugar white vinegar
combination and all we need to do is
give that a mix and set it aside as we
prep our apples which we're going to go
ahead and cube up and to do that we
should probably peel them first and i'm
using some nice beautiful tart crisp
green apples i forget the names of these
but they're very similar to granny smith
which would work perfectly
and once we peel our apple we're going
to go ahead and cut in quarters
and then to remove the core i just like
to set it down flat like this and make a
little 45 degree angle cut right there
and once we've trimmed the seed slash
core from the center take each of those
quarters and cut it twice like that and
then we'll just turn it and cut across
into i don't know what are those half
inch pieces
as usual the size is up to you pick a
size and stick with it
but i think something close to the size
right here would work out perfectly and
of course there's a reason we mixed up
our sugar vinegar first as you're
cutting these apples just toss them
right in the pan
and of course that will prevent them
from browning so i went ahead and i
cubed up four apples total and we'll
just make sure those are all kind of
coated with that vinegar before we move
on at that point we can move on to prop
our apricots so in addition to the apple
we're gonna do a little bit of dried
apricots and i'm gonna dice these kind
of small before adding them
and usually this is the time of year
that some food blogger recommends
spraying your knife with oil so it's
easier to cut your dried fruit i've
never been a big fan of that i mean sure
i guess dried fruit sticking to your
knife would be kind of annoying but you
know what else is annoying cutting your
finger off because you're using a
slippery knife it's no greasy blade for
me
but anyway i'm going to dice up some
dried apricot and toss that in with the
apple
along with some golden raisins i'm also
going to add four or five nice thick
slices of fresh peeled ginger and for
the ginger the strategy is either make
it really small so it disappears or
really big so you can pull it out later
so i'm gonna go with the always popular
pull it out when you're done system
we're also gonna add some shallot
you could certainly substitute with some
red onion or regular onion but i do love
the flavor shallot and it also gives us
a nice little blushy color but of course
that's up to you you are the boss of
your apple chutney that you probably end
up calling sauce i'm also going to put
in a little bit of hot pepper flake you
could just use regular chili flakes i'm
using aleppo pepper which is awesome and
then we're also going to add one star
nice check it out one of the most exotic
looking spices ever tastes as delicious
as it looks dangerous at that point
we're going to bring this over to the
stove and put it on medium high heat and
bring it up to a simmer probably not a
bad idea to give it a stir but anyway
like i said let's go ahead and bring
this up to a simmer on medium-high heat
and we'll go ahead and add the final
ingredients which includes a little bit
of mustard seed it's gonna of course
give it a little flavor but a very very
cool visual effect and then we're
definitely gonna need some salt in a
decent amount so i'm gonna go ahead and
toss in some kosher salt and we'll stir
that in
and this would be the absolute perfect
time to go check your fridge for odds
and ends any kind of leftover peppers
would be great
citrus maybe you got a few skelens you
forgot about i mean chutney is a great
catch-all for that kind of stuff i
didn't have anything like that but i did
remember i do want to put some garlic in
this so my last official ingredient will
be some minced garlic then we'll stir
that in
and then the rest of this procedure is
extremely easy we're simply going to
simmer this for about 40 to 45 minutes
and i'll say to reduce your heat to
medium low and use that but really
you're going to have to adjust what
you're going to shoot for is something
that looks like this so it's not really
a boil it's not really a slow gentle
simmer it's something in between
and besides giving it a stir once in a
while there's really nothing else to do
so we'll go ahead and let that cook
we'll of course monitor the heat
and like i said give it a stir once in a
while
and eventually about 40-45 minutes later
it should look something like this
all right the liquids have definitely
reduced our fruit is basically collapsed
and softened but definitely still has a
chunkiness to it at this point all we're
going to do is remove it from the heat
let it cool down to room temperature and
then refrigerate it until needed and by
the way just like when you make jam this
is going to get much much thicker when
it cools so do not worry if you think
it's too loose at this point it will
definitely tighten up and firm up as it
chills and as i mentioned earlier before
you serve this you'll want to pull out
those ginger chunks and the star knees
hey nothing spoils a fancy holiday meal
like a lawsuit so be careful and of
course please let that stuff cool down
before you wrap it and put in the fridge
so do as i say not as i just did for the
sake of the filming and then once that
is completely chilled you can pull it
out
give it a stir and then taste for
seasoning you really do have to sample
this when it's cold to get an accurate
taste so we'll taste for salt mostly if
you want to add a little more heat go
ahead and once your chutney's been
seasoned and all choking risks have been
removed we'll transfer that into some
kind of attractive serving dish and
you're ready to enjoy your spiced apple
chutney and let me tell you not only is
this stuff gorgeous it is just
absolutely mind-blowingly delicious i
mean seriously if you like applesauce
you are gonna go nuts for this stuff you
put this stuff on pork chops or holiday
hams or any of the other usual suspects
you'd serve applesauce with and you
won't believe how amazing this is now
unfortunately for me i have to do the
taste test on a piece of bread since i
was fresh out of pork chops and holiday
hams but even on a humble piece of toast
it's just unbelievably good and like i
said if you have to trick your family
and call it applesauce instead of
chutney go ahead not gonna hurt my
feelings you gotta do what you gotta do
but anyway no matter what you call it
this is just a beautiful beautiful
special occasion condiment and one i
hope you give a try to very very soon so
head over to foodwishes.com for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual
and as always enjoy
you
